resource.chars:
Behind the stomach the intestine consists of four 
parts: first a short, constricted piece; second a dilated,
oval division; third a short rectum; and fourth an 
anal tube. The stomach has an epithelium lining,
which is thrown up into folds so as to form im-
perfectly differentiated glandular follicles. After
removing the epithelium, the characteristic arrange-
ment of the muscular fibres is readily seen under 
the microscope (Fig.3). There is an internal layer,
composed of a large number of fibres, running trans-
versely around the stomach and more or less parallel 
to one another. Outside are the longitudinal striped 
muscles, which are distributed in single bundles,
and do not form a continuous layer. Each bundle 
is composed of a number of fibres and pursues 
its own course; the bundles are not parallel, but 
sometimes two bundles unite, or are connected 
by a third; their general direction is longitudinal.
Numerous tracheal branches penetrate the muscular 
layers, and ramify both through them and the
